be:\r\n```java\r\nclass BitwardenItemLogin {\r\n  /** May be an otpauth:// URI, or just a secret. */\r\n  String totp;\r\n}\r\n\r\nclass BitwardenItem {\r\n  BitwardenItemLogin login;\r\n  String name;\r\n}\r\n\r\nclass BitwardenVault {\r\n  List<BitwardenItem> items;\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nI am less familiar with deserializing .csv to POJOs, but the relevant column header is `login_totp`; in the example file I have, it is the 11th column.\r\n\r\nTOTP support is currently a premium feature in Bitwarden, but I would be happy to help test the functionality; my personal device is rooted, so I should be able to install a test .apk if \"New User\" experience when moving between devices","body":"###### Info\r\n\r\n* __Version__: 2.02\r\n* __Source__: F-Droid\r\n* __Vault encrypted__: Yes, with biometric unlock\r\n* __Device__: Motorola One Vision\r\n* __Android version and ROM__: LineageOS 15\r\n\r\n###### Description\r\n\r\nThe user experience when moving from one device to another is extremely unintuitive. In order to complete the welcome wizard, you have to create a new database, which is fine for new users, but for users with an existing database (such as a user who upgraded to a new phone), you have to create a new database, then import all your old entries manually from a backup. If you wish to keep reusing the same password, you have to manually set the new database to use the same password as the backup one. It would be nice if this was a little easier and more streamlined. I was actually confused for a second on what to do because I was specifically looking for an \"import\" button in the welcome wizard. I am a power user so I figured it out pretty quickly, but a less experienced user might get very confused that they have to create a new database in order to use their existing one.\r\n\r\n###### Steps to reproduce\r\n\r\n1. Use Aegis on your old phone\r\n2. Backup your aegis database on your old phone using the exporter\r\n3. Get a new phone (or simply delete aegis and it's data) and transfer the backup over to the new device\r\n4. Install aegis on the new phone\r\n5. In the Welcome to Aegis screen, press next\r\n6. Set a new password for a new vault (set the same password you're used to)\r\n7. Go to settings\r\n8. Import your old vault backup\r\n9. Type the password (even though it's the same as your new one) and press OK\r\n10. Import the vault contents\r\n11. You now have something resembling what you had before\r\n\r\n###### What do you expect to happen?\r\n\r\nRestoring a backup on a new device/install should be an easy, straightforward experience.\r\n\r\nI propose something like this:\r\n\r\n1. Use Aegis on your old phone\r\n2. Backup your aegis database on your old phone using the exporter\r\n3. Get a new phone (or simply delete aegis and it's data) and transfer the backup over to the new device\r\n4. Install aegis on the new phone\r\n5. After the first welcome screen (the one with the aegis logo), there's a new screen with 2 buttons, New Database or Restore From Backup\r\n6. press \"Restore from Backup\"\r\n7. Select the backup file\r\n8. The app will ask for your database password\r\n9. Type it and press OK\r\n10. Aegis is now ready to go in the same way it was when you used it on your other phone\r\n\r\n###### What happens instead?\r\n\r\nIt's clunky as you need to make a new database (and use the same password manually if you want the same experience) and import the entries yourself in the settings menu.\r\n\r\n###### More Info\r\n\r\nThis will make for a much quicker/nicer experience when moving from an old phone to a new one.\r\n\r\nObviously this isn't really a \"bug\" in the strictest sense, it's more a usability issue. It should probably be considered low priority as a result.\r\n\r\nEDIT: In hindsight, I should have probably made this a feature request, not a bug made\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/839\r\nhttps://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/859\r\n\r\nand the answer\r\n\r\n`You're probably seeing the password reminder. Try entering your password once. After that, Aegis should start prompting biometrics by default again.`\r\n\r\nAnd that's true, but I hit \"use password\" multiple times by mistake, anyone who has a big thumb can hit the \"use password\" by mistake, it's a pain to keep fetching the password every time someone pick that option by mistake.  It'd be awesome to add a default biometric option, so that if you switch to password and switch back to biometric, it saves the biometric.\r\n\r\nSo I think a better behaviour would be to save the Keystore key invalidated after device unlock on Pixel 4","body":"#### Info\r\n\r\n* __Version__: 2.0.2\r\n* __Source__: Google Play\r\n* __Vault encrypted__: Yes, with password and biometric unlock\r\n* __Device__: Pixel 4\r\n* __Android version and ROM__: Android 11 stock\r\n\r\n#### Steps to reproduce\r\n\r\n- Unlock phone\r\n- Open Aegis with biometric (face) unlock\r\n\r\n#### What do you expect to happen?\r\n\r\nI do not get asked for my Aegis password\r\n\r\n#### What happens instead?\r\n\r\nAegis \"detects a change in biometric security\" and asks for my password again.\r\n\r\nThe Google Pixel 4 (and probably newer Pixels) will \"improve\" the face matching with each successful device unlock, and so Aegis detects that the biometric security \"changed\", even though it's still the same face that is saved.\r\n\r\nIdeally, being able to detect whether face unlock has been *removed entirely* and re-added would be a better alternative, but I don't think that's possible through whatever API Android exposes.\r\n\r\nAs a second proposal, an option to turn off this detection (with a warning of what it means, of course), would be nice to have, as I store my Aegis password on an air-gapped computer and it is inconvenient to not be able to access my 2fa tokens when not at Biometric Security","body":"I've used some other apps where, the first time you run the app after restarting the phone, you must login using your password, not just the fingerprint sensor.\r\n\r\nThis is important because in some jurisdictions you can be compelled to provide your fingerprint, but not a password.\r\n\r\nI understand that the security of a 2fa app is less important than that of a password - more often than not, the device itself is the security - but since this is security focused, I still think it's a good idea.\r\n\r\nI also feel personally uncomfortable with someone being able to use just my fingerprint to unlock the device. I'd like the ability to completely disable biometrics entirely if possible.\r\n\r\nI propose the following changes:\r\n\r\n1. Upon starting the app for the first time after restarting, the first login requires the password\r\n2. When using the lock item in the menu, it will also require the password to log in.\r\n3. Add an option to completely disable biometrics\r\n\r\nAlso, unrelated, here's a question: if I've NEVER used biometrics for the app, and law enforcement uses the \"or login using Biometric security\" link, will they then be able to use my fingerprint to log in - a login method I never consented to? That seems like a pretty major security oversight.\r\n\r\nMaybe I'm being overly paranoid T-Mobile breach. \r\n\r\n- Found a WaPo article which included the following: \r\n\r\n> Rethink two-factor authentication\r\nIf you\u2019re even mildly security-conscious, you might already have two-factor authentication enabled on some of your online accounts - and that\u2019s good thinking. Here\u2019s the rub, though: If you\u2019re concerned your data has been compromised as part of this breach, it might be time to rethink how you use 2FA.\r\n\r\n> Let\u2019s say an attacker manages to obtain your name, date of birth and Social Security number  - if they luck out and find your address and reused password in other data dumps, that might be enough to give them access to your T-Mobile account. If that happens, you could be vulnerable to what\u2019s called a SIM-swap attack, in which the hacker manages to switch control of your phone number to a phone they control. That\u2019s definitely bad, but what could make it worse is if the verification codes sent by services like Amazon, Twitter and many banks are delivered via text message. In that case, the keys to your online kingdom could be ferried straight to someone else.\r\n\r\n> One possible fix: Lee suggests using, whenever possible, authenticator apps from companies like Google and Microsoft that live directly on your phone. \u201cJust having the text or the email that goes to the device is not as secure as having that authenticator app,\u201d he said. \u201cWe always recommend to consumers that they use that, and to businesses that they offer that.\"\r\n\r\n- Searched for \"open source 2FA app\", installed & set up Aegis and now have the opportunity to use it while signing up to make a credit freeze with Equifax.\r\n\r\n- Here's the reason for this help thread: on the page where it's asking to send a verification code, it only gives the options to select phone or email. And in the Aegis app, my option appears to be clicking the red plus, then either scanning a qr code, scanning an image or manually setting up an entry with info I'm not familiar with and don't believe is provided by the issuing website's verification page.\r\n\r\n- Is this a scenario where using such an authentication app (Aegis, Google, MS, etc) _only_ works if the issuing website in question actually lists a specified option to 'use Aegis Authenticator app\", or \"use Google Authenticator app\", etc?\r\n\r\nI must be missing something obvious.\r\nI checked the faqs but didn't find the answer. \r\n\r\nAny feedback would be appreciated! to Disable Automatic Refresh for Selected Code","body":"I would like to add a feature to the app that enables users to pause the updating of the selected entry.\r\n\r\nMost of the time when using Aegis, I only wish to generate just one code. There is, in my opinion, no reason to automatically refresh a code once the timer runs out. On top of that, it's a little annoying to have a code change when I'm halfway through reading it. This feature will solve that.\r\n\r\nIf a user has this setting enabled, the selected item in the entry list would not automatically refresh when the timer runs out. When the item loses focus (either by selecting a different entry or after the \"tap to reveal\" countdown ended), it will once again be subject to the periodic updates.\r\n\r\nI think this option will be most useful in combination with the \"tap to reveal\" functionality. It will ensure that only one code is shown to the user. After all, isn't that what \"tap to reveal\" is all the non-standard Authy TOTP algorithm","body":"Authy's server-side validation currently accepts codes generated according to RFC 4226 but it may be useful to directly use the Android app's slightly bizarre (why?) algorithm:\r\n\r\n 1. The counter value is normally represented as a 64-bit big-endian integer when passed into HMAC-SHA1. Authy instead *directly uses the counter value as a base-10 ASCII string*. For example, the counter 12345678 would not be represented as `\\x00\\x00\\x00\\x00\\x00\\xBC\\x61\\x4E`, but as the bytes `12345678`.\r\n 2. The OTP secret is normally decoded from its base32 representation when it's used as the HMAC-SHA1 key. Authy decodes the base32-encoded secret *and then re-encodes it as lowercase ASCII hex*. For example, the secret `AEBAGBAFAYDQQ` would not be decoded into `\\x01\\x02\\x03\\x04\\x05\\x06\\x07\\x08`, but instead the ASCII string `0102030405060708` would be used.\r\n\r\nTo distinguish these codes from \"normal\" TOTP codes, I propose using a new URI type:\r\n\r\n```\r\notpauth://authy/...\r\n          ^^^^^\r\n```\r\n\r\nYou can test out the algorithm yourself with this self-contained Python script that generate pairs of RFC 4226 and \"Authy\" codes from a given secret: https://github.com/puddly/android-otp-extractor/issues/34#issuecomment-634447781\r\n\r\nThis is probably an unnecessary change as long as the Authy desktop app is still using RFC 4226 but if that changes in the future, you may find this info useful.\r\n\r\nThank you for the awesome app!","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/776/labels{/name}","author_association":"NONE","number":776,"updated_at":"2022-08-06T09:45:09Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/776/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":920980136,"state":"closed","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/776/timeline","state_reason":"completed","comments":4,"closed_at":"2021-06-23T10:39:58Z","url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/776","labels":[{"default":false,"color":"84b6eb","name":"proposal","description":"A shortcut for applying group filter","body":"This adds a shortcut for applying a given group filter. Clicking on the shortcut opens the app and applies the group filter that was saved. This is useful for rapidly viewing entries for a specific group.\r\n\r\nCurrently the app only generates a shortcut for the current group filter. The way Android handles shortcuts is that the intent gets saved with the shortcut, so even if the group filter within the app is changed/removed, the group filter for the shortcut stays the same. If you want to create one shortcut for group \"foo\" and another for group \"bar\", you'd set the group filter to \"foo\", go to home screen, drag the shortcut \"Open group foo\" to home screen, open the app, change the group filter to \"bar\", go to home screen, and drag the shortcut for \"Open group bar\" to homescreen. At this point tapping on the \"foo\" icon would open the app with the \"foo\" filter applied, and tapping on the \"bar\" icon would open the app with the \"bar\" filter applied. Group filters with multiple groups selected is also supported.\r\n\r\nTODOs:\r\n* find/make an appropriate icon for the shortcut\r\n\r\n<img width=\"300\" secret invalid input length","body":"<!-- Please read the [bug reports section of the contribution\r\nguidelines](/CONTRIBUTING.md#bug-reports) before submitting an issue. -->\r\n\r\n###### Info\r\n\r\n* __Version__: 2.0\r\n* __Source__: Google Play\r\n* __Vault encrypted__: Yes with biometric unlock\r\n* __Device__: Android\r\n* __Android version and ROM__: Not relevant\r\n\r\n###### Steps to reproduce\r\n\r\nI wanted to test the interface of Aegis (I'm comparing it with other apps), so I generated a random 2FA QR code to add.\r\n\r\n1) Go to https://stefansundin.github.io/2fa-qr/ (2FA QR code generator)\r\n2) Configure with \"Time based TOTP\" + \"secretkey\" + \"Test 2FA\"\r\n3) Scan the QR code with Aegis Auth\r\n\r\n###### What do you expect to happen?\r\n\r\nThe QR code is added (it worked with 2FA Authenticator)\r\n\r\n###### What happens instead?\r\n\r\nQR code is refused with an error and not added to my vault\r\n\r\n###### Log\r\n\r\nError happened while trying to time and date for last login","body":"Some websites show you the time and date of your current and last session, sometimes just after logging in, to allow you to check for suspicious activities you don't remember. GitHub, for example, has a full security log:\r\n\r\n![securitylog](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37388405/120898649-4e006f00-c61b-11eb-8deb-8ad70299871c.png)\r\n\r\nBut I won't remember the last time I logged into a website for long, especially if it's a website I seldom log into. I'd like to propose using Aegis as a reminder.\r\n\r\nThe simplest method I can think of is remembering only one timestamp and replacing it manually with the current time and date, like in this (crude) mockup:\r\n![mockup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37388405/120899130-aafd2480-c61d-11eb-8b85-9a48e2fa257d.png)\r\n\r\nWith this method, just after you log into an account, you would tap into your authenticator code (if you hadn't already), then check your last session date and time, and if they match, just tap the blue button to record this session's date and time. Repeat for every login. If your timestamp doesn't match the website's last timestamp, your account has been probably not-very-stealthily hijacked.\r\n\r\nThere are some problems with this method (the user has to be aware of timezone problems, it only detects a very specific kind of attack) and it's much less convenient on websites that don't show you your last session, but on those that do (like `europa.eu`) it could help detect these attacks with very little effort.","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/765/labels{/name}","author_association":"NONE","number":765,"updated_at":"2021-08-25T13:47:10Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/765/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":912349764,"state":"closed","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/765/timeline","state_reason":"completed","comments":3,"closed_at":"2021-08-25T13:47:10Z","url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/765","labels":[{"default":false,"color":"84b6eb","name":"proposal","description":"A image\" in Aegis to create a new entry. \r\n\r\nIt would be nice if Aegis could instead scan QR code images received via share intents (`ACTION_SEND`). This would allow users to simply long press on the QR code in their browser, choose \"share image\" and select Aegis to create a new entry, without actually having to save the image and finding it in the file picker.\r\n\r\nOf course this is not limited to web browser and could also be used from other apps, e.g. from a file picker or a gallery app to open a QR code image in Aegis. \r\n\r\nCaveat: Unfortunately it seems like only some browsers (e.g. Chrome) actually share images as \"images\" (Intents with type `image/...`). Firefox only shares the URL to the image when using the \"share image\" function.\r\n\r\nIf this sounds like a good idea I could open a importing from other apps' ADB backup files (.ab)","body":"Obtaining an ADB backup file for an app on non-rooted phone is about 3 times easier than figuring out how to extract the file with the secrets from that archive.\r\n\r\nAegis could offer \"Import from ADB backup\" option which would make it way easier to migrate to Aegis for non-rooted phone users like myself.\r\n\r\nI would then run `adb backup ...` command and give the .ab file to Aegis after selecting which app it is for. And Aegis would take care of figuring out which file is needed and extracting it from the backup.\r\n(It could probably even detect the application automatically by analyzing the contents of the backup.)\r\n\r\nHere is for instance an instruction for how to obtain the FreeOTP's `tokens.xml` file:\r\nhttps://thevaliantway.com/2018/08/freeotp-migration/\r\n(TL;DR: `adb backup ...` + `dd ...` to chop off the first 24 bytes + `printf ...` to prepend the archive signature + `tar`/`gz` to extract the dark theme variants of the fullscreen style","body":"Fixes #658.\r\n\r\nThe current full screen style does not support the Dark and AMOLED themes. This change adds two new full screen themes, `AppTheme.Fullscreen.Dark` and `AppTheme.Fullscreen.TrueBlack`. A new ThemeMap is added, `FULLSCREEN`, which is now  used by the ScannerActivity to set an appropriately themed full screen style.\r\n\r\nI would have preferred to simply merge the existing `AppTheme.Fullscreen` style with an appropriate `DEFAULT` ThemeMap value but I could not find a way to merge two styles together, nor apply multiple styles at the same time. Additionally, since style inheritance is limited to a single parent, I could not inherit from more than one style when creating the new full screen styles. for Steam Desktop Authenticator to Aegis App","body":"Hey, i had some problems adding Steam to Aegis, as i am using the Steam Desktop Authenticator App on my pc, and i do not have a rooted android device. So i though i would write this guide to help others!\r\n\r\nFirst off you need to open your SDA (Steam Desktop Authenticator) file directory, and find the *.maFile inside maFiles folder (Open it with notepad) . In there you will see all the data you need like shared_secret and more. \r\n\r\nThen create a new file name Steamguard-myConfig.json on your desktop(It has to be in json format), and copy-paste all the contents of the maFile into the new json file. \r\n\r\nThen connect your android phone to your pc and open the file directory and copy the file into the Downloads folder (Or any other you have access to on the phone). \r\n\r\nAfter doing that you need to open Aegis and go into settings and scroll all the way down and click on import from file. Choose Steam as the option and click Ok. Then select the newly imported Steamguard-myConfig.json file. \r\n\r\nYou should now have your steam code inside Aegis as well!\r\n\r\nHope my guide helped someone! unlocked with biometrics.\r\nThis can be problematic, because if you are forced you can't say that you don't know the password. Also there are countries where it's not allowed for police officers to force you to input your password, but they are not denied from holding your hand to the fingerprint reader ([source](https://www.wired.com/story/police-unlock-iphone-face-id-legal-rights/))\r\n\r\nI would like to request to not automatically open the biometrics popup if biometrics unlock is configured.\r\nAlso, if you currently only show the \"Or tap here to use biometrics\" text if biometrics unlock is configured, I would like to request to make it unconditional, so it's always shown, with the difference that the popup would never accept the fingerprint.\r\n\r\nWhile this does not solve the actual problem, that with forcing you the app could be unlocked, this could help you persuade the other party that biometrics unlock is not set up (e.g. by setting it up for an other finger on your hand, or for a finger on your toe, which nobody would think to #54\r\n\r\n\r\n","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/510/labels{/name}","author_association":"MEMBER","number":510,"updated_at":"2020-08-01T11:04:13Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"draft":false,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/510/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":651113272,"state":"closed","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/510/timeline","pull_request":{"patch_url":"https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/pull/510.patch","html_url":"https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/pull/510","merged_at":"2020-08-01T11:04:12Z","diff_url":"https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/pull/510.diff","url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/pulls/510"},"state_reason":null,"comments":0,"closed_at":"2020-08-01T11:04:13Z","url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/510","labels":[],"milestone":null,"events_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/510/events","html_url":"https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/pull/510","reactions":{"confused":0,"-1":0,"total_count":0,"+1":0,"rocket":0,"hooray":0,"eyes":0,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/510/reactions","laugh":0,"heart":0},"assignee":null,"user":{"gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/gists{/gist_id}","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/repos","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/following{/other_user}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/starred{/owner}{/repo}","login":"michaelschattgen","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/followers","type":"User","url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/subscriptions","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/received_events","avatar_url":"https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7524012?v=4","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/events{/privacy}","html_url":"https://github.com/michaelschattgen","site_admin":false,"id":7524012,"gravatar_id":"","node_id":"MDQ6VXNlcjc1MjQwMTI=","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/michaelschattgen/orgs"},"node_id":"MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NDQ0NDM4MzYy"},{"assignees":[],"created_at":"2020-07-05T16:31:38Z","title":"Icon packs","body":"We've recently been thinking some more about how to improve icon support in Aegis. Lots of users have been using [krisu5's icon\r\npack](https://github.com/krisu5/aegis-icons) as a source for icons in Aegis. The icon pack is great, but it's a bit of a pain for users to use, and that's Aegis' fault. To make the experience better, we want to introduce support for icon packs.\r\n\r\nThe idea is that creators of icon packs format their releases in the standard way described in this proposal, so that Aegis can read and use them. \r\n\r\nThis way, we can keep the maintenance of icons packs and Aegis itself separate, while also offering users the ability to use/create icon packs without being forced to use the one provided by the app.\r\n\r\n@krisu5 We'd appreciate your feedback on this.\r\n\r\n### The format\r\n\r\nIcon packs are .ZIP archives with a collection of icons and a ``pack.json`` file. The icon pack definition is a JSON file, formatted like the example below. All icon packs have a name, a UUID, a version and a list of icons. The version number is incremented when a new version of the icon pack is released. The UUID is randomly generated once and stays the same across different versions.\r\n\r\n```json\r\n{\r\n    \"uuid\": \"e77dbfb5-30d6-468d-bf74-37f07734bcf5\",\r\n    \"name\": \"Kristian's Icon Pack\",\r\n    \"version\": 1,\r\n    \"icons\": [\r\n        {\r\n            \"filename\": \"services/Google.png\",\r\n            \"category\": \"Services\",\r\n            \"issuer\": [ \"google\" ]\r\n        },\r\n        {\r\n            \"filename\": \"services/Blizzard.png\",\r\n            \"category\": \"Gaming\",\r\n            \"issuer\": [ \"blizzard\", \"battle.net\" ]\r\n        }\r\n    ]\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nEvery icon definition contains the filename of the icon file, relative to the root of the .ZIP archive. Icon definitions also have a list of strings that the Issuer field in Aegis is matched against for automatic selection of an icon for new entries. Matching is done in a case-insensitve manner. There's also a category field.\r\n\r\nThe following image formats are supported, in order of preference:\r\n\r\n| Name | MIME          | Extension |\r\n|:-----|:--------------|:----------|\r\n| SVG  | image/svg+xml | .svg      |\r\n| PNG  | image/png     | .png      |\r\n| JPEG | image/jpeg    | .jpg      |\r\n\r\nAny files in the .ZIP archive that are not the ``pack.json`` file or referred to in the icons list are ignored. Such files are not extracted when importing the icon pack into Aegis.\r\n\r\n### Changes to Aegis' vault format\r\n\r\nSupporting multiple image formats also means that we have to make a small change to Aegis' vault format. Aegis currently only stores and expects JPEG images. We'd have to introduce a new ``icon_mime`` field for entries to store the MIME type of the icon. When loading older vaults, entries that do not have that field will try to parse the icon as JPEG.\r\n\r\nI previously proposed moving icons out of the vault file entirely in #134, but that would be a much larger change, and has stalled improvements to our icon support. We can revisit if that's still desirable later.\r\n\r\nWe may also have to increment the vault format version, because previous versions of Aegis will no longer be able to load vaults with these changes.\r\n\r\n### Using icon packs in Aegis\r\n\r\nUsers can download an icon pack from the internet and import it into Aegis through the settings menu. Aegis extracts the icon pack to ``icons/{uuid}/{version}``, relative to its internal storage directory. So for the example icon pack above, that'd be:\r\n``icons/e77dbfb5-30d6-468d-bf74-37f07734bcf5/1.0``. If it has an old version of the icon pack, it will be removed after successful extraction of the newer version. \r\n\r\nAfter that, Aegis will start proposing icons for new entries if the issuer matches with one of the icons in the pack. We'll also have an icon selection dialog, where all of the icons in the pack appear. When the user selects an icon, it is copied and stored in the vault file.\r\n","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/509/labels{/name}","author_association":"MEMBER","number":509,"updated_at":"2021-06-12T16:55:04Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/509/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":651101670,"state":"closed","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/509/timeline","state_reason":"completed","comments":39,"closed_at":"2021-04-10T08:50:36Z","url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/509","labels":[{"default":false,"color":"4393e8","name":"proposal-accepted","description":"An discoverability of drag-and-drop feature","body":"Hi there! I have been using Aegis for a while and love the features it provides.\r\n\r\nAegis currently supports a drag and drop feature for reordering items with the following procedure:\r\n1. Long press an item, then release\r\n2. Long press the item again and hold\r\n3. Drag the item to the desired location\r\n\r\nThis is unintuitive and hard for users to discover. It seems I'm not the only one too: #482 #322 #357\r\n\r\nIn most other apps, drag and drop can be done by simply long-pressing the item and dragging. There is no need to release before selecting the item again. Alternatively, many apps add a drag handle which the user can use to move items around. It would be great if you could implement something similar to improve usability.\r\n\r\nBased on what I've seen of your code, you should be able to implement this using the [startDrag function in ItemTouchHelper](https://developer.android.com/reference/androidx/recyclerview/widget/ItemTouchHelper#startDrag(androidx.recyclerview.widget.RecyclerView.ViewHolder)). If you want, I can try my hand at implementing this myself (though it may take a while as I'm not familiar with your codebase).\r\n\r\nI hope you'll take my suggestion into account. Either way, thanks so much for making this great app! \r\n\r\nExample of drag handles in Plus import without depending on SQLCipher","body":"As mentioned in #388 the possibility of importing encrypted Authenticator Plus databases is bloating the APK too much. This is due to the SQLCiper library shipping binaries for different architectures.\r\n\r\nIt is possible to use the export functionality to generate an encrypted ZIP archive which contains a plain list of URLs in the standard format described in #138. From here we have two possibilities:\r\n\r\n- Letting the user extract the archive and then import using the \"Plain text\" import from #359. Depending on the default file manager the user might need to install one with support for encrypted archives (the Android \"Files\" app can't do that, whereas OnePlus's file manager can).\r\n\r\n- Extract the archive for the user which might sadly generate another dependency, as extracting encrypted archives seems not possible with native tools.\r\n\r\nI personally would opt for the first option, as both don't support keeping categories and implementing the whole extracting stuff just doesn't feel right, as most of the necessary import logic is already Unlock Does Not Work On OnePlus 7 Pro","body":"<!-- Please read the [bug reports section of the contribution\r\nguidelines](/CONTRIBUTING.md#bug-reports) before submitting an issue. -->\r\n\r\n###### Info\r\n\r\n* __Version__: 1.1.4\r\n* __Source__: Google Play\r\n* __Vault encrypted:__ Yes with biometrics\r\n* __Device:__ OnePlus 7 Pro\r\n* __Android version and ROM:__ OxygenOS 10.0.5.GM21BA (Android 10)\r\n\r\nAegis can't be unlocked with fingerprint sensor on the OnePlus 7 Pro. Unlocking with password is working fine. Restarting the device does not fix the issue.\r\n\r\nAegis was installed on Android 9 before update to Android 10. The vault was imported from Nokia 6.1.\r\n\r\n###### Steps to reproduce\r\n\r\n1. Setup Aegis with biometric unlock\r\n2. Lock the vault and exit app\r\n3. Open Aegis and try to authenticate with fingerprint\r\n4. Aegis says Couldn't unlock vault: Incorrect password. Make sure you didn't mistype your password\r\n5. adapt to system theme","body":"added an implementation of Android 10 (API 29) dark theme\r\n\r\nadded two new theme options:\r\nSYSTEM: dynamically switches between light and dark theme\r\nSYSTEM_AMOLED: dynamically switches between light and amoled theme\r\n\r\nchanged the default theme to be SYSTEM\r\n\r\nreversed [this workaround](https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/commit/59c0ca947dfec842e7b24fcddca34538bcc709d2) for amoled themed preferences to remove duplicated code in `PreferencesActivity.java`\r\n(I'm not sure why this workaround was needed but I just added the true dark background to the normal amoled theme)\r\n\r\nThe launch screen will always follow the system theme regardless of which theme was selected. There is no other way to do it because the color of the launch screen can only be set in XML which means no preferences can be queried. Following the system theme is still an improvement from always showing a white screen.\r\n\r\ncloses #115 \r\n\r\n**TODO**\r\n- [x] change theme based on the system theme\r\n- [x] launch screen is SpongyCastle with BouncyCastle","body":"SpongyCastle is a fork of BouncyCastle. We originally used this fork to 1) have access to scrypt and 2) prevent a package name collision with the bundled BouncyCastle. We don't actually need to use the fork anymore, because the package name of the bundled BouncyCastle was changed in Android. SpongyCastle has also gotten quite outdated in recent years.\r\n\r\nThe built-in version of BouncyCastle is replaced with the one bundled with the app at runtime, so that we have a recent version even on older Android versions.\r\n\r\nThis also updates Gradle and the Gradle Android plugin, to fix a build error I was running into when I added the dependency to BouncyCastle.\r\n\r\nFixes Just came across it today, and am loving it!\r\n\r\nI had a thought about a small UX request, as currently when editing the picture for an entry, the user flow is to:\r\n- Tap the current icon\r\n- find an icon image in their gallery app of choice\r\n- select that image\r\n- Select the checkmark icon at the bottom right of the dark-gray crop overlay screen\r\n- Press save at the top right\r\n\r\nEspecially when cropping an image after selecting, this process seems somewhat self-evident. However in a case were adding premade/pre-sized/pre-cropped icons (ie from the community icon pack), the crop overlay aligns perfectly with the background, making it easier to miss that the image is in \"edit\" mode. If one does miss this, and select the Save button at the top, the image will not be saved, and the user will have to start the process over again.\r\n\r\nWould it then be possible to modify the image selection behavior with one (or a combination) of tweaks for better usability:\r\n - A text tooltip indicating \"Crop/Edit\" mode is active\r\n - Save currently shown crop/edit of image when \"Save\" is selected\r\n - Launch a dialogue asking the user to save/discard the unsaved changes (or cancel the action of saving) \r\n\r\nThese are just some ideas about small tweaks, but feel free to suggest others or modify them as needed. This allows the user to immediately change the password without any verification that the password was typed correctly using the `Confirm password` text box. Even though the user can plainly see the password, this is still dangerous.\r\n\r\n###### writes of the vault file against corruption with AtomicFile","body":"This adds a recovery mechanism for (probably extremely rare) cases where the app may be killed before it is finished writing the vault file to disk. In the example below, we see that AtomicFile moved ``aegis.json`` to ``aegis.json.bak`` before writing to ``aegis.json``.\r\n\r\n```\r\nbonito:/ # ls -lah /data/data/com.beemdevelopment.aegis.debug/files\r\ntotal 27M\r\ndrwxrwx--x 2 u0_a306 u0_a306 3.4K 2020-02-02 13:22 .\r\ndrwx------ 6 u0_a306 u0_a306 3.4K 2020-02-01 19:51 ..\r\n-rw------- 1 u0_a306 u0_a306  19M 2020-02-02 13:22 aegis.json\r\n-rw------- 1 u0_a306 u0_a306  34M 2020-02-02 13:21 aegis.json.bak\r\n```\r\n\r\nBecause the app was killed before it could finish writing, it is only 19M in size, instead of the expected 34M. The next time the app starts, AtomicFile will notice that the .bak file is still present, and use that instead of the corrupted ``aegis.json`` file.\r\n\r\nClose there a security benefit in using the app based encryption when the phone is already using full disk encryption?","body":"Some arguments I could think of:\r\n\r\n1. A user could accidentally copy the vault to an unencrypted location for example when performing a back up.\r\n2. The operating system might not sufficiently prevent malicious apps from accessing other app's data. Counterpoint: If the operating system has problems like this then even with app based encryption the malicious app might be able to record the keyboard or read Aegis' memory.\r\n3. The phone might get lost while it is running and would be in an unlocked state from the point of view of full disk encryption whereas Aegis immediately locks the vault after use.\r\n4. The full disk encryption might use weaker algorithms than the app based encryption.\r\n\r\nThis question might be relevant for other people so it could be added to the UUIDMap for storing objects that are keyed by a UUID","body":"This patch introduces the ``UUIDMap`` type, with the goal of reducing code duplication and improving UUID lookups. We currently already use UUIDs as the identifier for the ``DatabaseEntry`` and ``Slot`` types, but the way lookups by UUID work are kind of ugly, as we simply iterate over the list until we find a match. As we're probably going to have more types like this soon (groups and icons, for example), I figured it'd be good to abstract this away into a separate type and make it a map instead of a list.\r\n\r\nThe only thing that has gotten slower is the ``swap`` method. The internal ``LinkedHashMap`` retains insertion order with a linked list, but does not know about the position of the values, so we basically have to copy the entire map to simply swap two values. I don't think it's too big of a deal, because swap -operations still take much less than a millisecond even with large vaults, but suggestions for improving this are welcome.\r\n\r\nI had to update gradle and JUnit to be able to use the new ``assertThrows`` assertion method in tests, so this patch includes that as icons out of the vault file to a separate folder","body":"Today, we store everything in the vault file, even icons. This decision was made early on in the project to get quick and easy support for icons, but as more people are starting to use Aegis, this technical debt is starting to show issues all over. It's a source of performance issues and crashes. The most recent example of this is #130.\r\n\r\nTherefore, I propose to move icons out of the vault file, into a separate folder. This would allow us to load the vault separately from the icons, improving performance and stability, with the cost of some added complexity to the code. All icons would be stored in the ``icons`` folder, with random UUID's as filenames. I think we should still encrypt them, so entries in the vault also need a reference to their icon, along with some parameters for decryption. It'd look like this:\r\n\r\n```json\r\n\"icon\": {\r\n\t\"uuid\": \"01234567-89ab-cdef-0123-456789abcdef\",\r\n\t\"mime\": \"image/jpeg\",\r\n\t\"params\": {\r\n\t\t\"nonce\": \"0123456789abcdef01234567\",\r\n\t\t\"tag\": \"0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef\"\r\n\t}\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nAs icons are no longer included in the vault, they would also not be included in exports. We'd have to use some kind of container format to export the vault along with all of the icons, like ``zip`` or ``tar``. Java seems to have a decent API to create zip files, so we might as well use that, but I'd rather have something that doesn't do compression as we won't benefit much from that anyway.\r\n\r\nThe only security-related consequence is that someone with access to the vault would be able to determine the (minimum) amount of entries the vault contains. I think that's We originally used this fork to 1) have access to scrypt and 2) prevent a package name collision with the bundled BouncyCastle. We don't actually need to use the fork anymore, because the package name of the bundled BouncyCastle was changed in Android. SpongyCastle has also gotten quite outdated in recent years.\r\n\r\nThis also replaces the built-in version of BouncyCastle with the one bundled with the app, so that we have a recent version even on older Android versions. 5T12:00:42Z","title":"Use the old encode method for passwords over 64 bytes and repair the slot","body":"Commit afb9e597110014117722fc8353333b18d3492007 fixed a bug where the password encode function would add null bytes to the end of the output. Luckily (I thought), PBKDF2 produces collisions for inputs with trailing null bytes and thus scrypt does this as well, so we could safely change that function to remove the null bytes without any impact. Unfortunately, that doesn't hold up if the password is over 64 bytes in size. So after that change, the KDF started producing different keys than before for such passwords and thus some users could no longer unlock their vault.\r\n\r\nThis patch addresses the issue by using the old password encode function for passwords over 64 bytes and repairing the affected password Strongbox for storage of Android KeyStore keys","body":"Some devices that ship with Android 9 or newer support an HSM-backed Keymaster, referred to as StrongBox. It's possible to indicate a preference for this by calling the ``setIsStrongBoxBacked`` function on the KeyGenerator. Doing this has some nice tin foil hat grade security benefits for the user with no apparent downsides, so I think this would be nice to enable by default.\r\n\r\nSee also:\r\n- https://developer.android.com/training/articles/keystore#HardwareSecurityModule\r\n- a bug where the password encode function added trailing null bytes","body":"Funny story. Instead of obtaining the actual bytes from the ByteBuffer in the password encode function, we obtained the entire buffer. This caused some trailing null bytes to be added to the encoded password. Luckily (and strangely), PBKDF2 produces collisions for inputs with trailing null bytes and thus scrypt does this as well. As such, this bug doesn't affect us right now, but it would if we were to use that encode function for other purposes in the future.\r\n\r\nThis also adds a test that checks for the expected collision behavior of If biometrics are required once the app has already initially opened, it appears to work okay. All other apps on the phone are working fine with biometrics, and this issue appears to have only begun after the v2.1 update the other day.\r\n\r\nWhat I have noticed is that when this issue occurs, I can briefly see what appears to be two prompts sliding up from the bottom of the screen when the biometric prompt appears. __Android version and ROM__: Android 12\r\n\r\n###### Steps to reproduce\r\n\r\nGo to Settings and tap on \"Language\", then select any language except English. Now return to the entry screen and add a new entry by tapping on \"+\" button, then tap on \"Create a new entry\" and save the new entry as it is. An error message will be shown, \"Secret is a required field.\"\r\n\r\n###### What do you expect to happen?\r\n\r\n\"Secret is a required field.\" string should be translatable.\r\n\r\n###### What happens instead?\r\n\r\n\"Secret is a requierd field\" is shown in English because its string key is missing on values(-XXX_rXX)/strings.xml file(s)\r\n\r\n###### Log\r\n\r\n```\r\nNo logs are necessary.\r\n```\r\n\r\n###### Additional notes\r\n\r\nLooking for that string on source I realized that EditEntryActivity.java file from java/com/beemdevelopment/aegis/ui/ contains some untranslatable strings. displaying expired TOTP token next to the new one","body":"Aegis has the same UX bug as nearly every other TOTP app. When the timer expires while you are typing a token, you have to start from scratch with the new code.\r\n\r\nI know that Aegis has an option to freeze a token when it is tapped, but that's just adding unnecessary work for the user.\r\nThe right solution would be to make sure the user can always see a token that will stay visible for at least half the TOTP time slot.\r\n\r\nThe andOTP app implements a simple solution for this: After a token expired, it is still shown on the side (in smaller letters), so that the user can complete their login.\r\n\r\nThe de-luxe solution would be a sliding window that always shows two tokens:\r\n- **Token1** | Token2 `// start: future token is shown on the right`\r\n- Token1 | **Token2** `// T1 expired`\r\n- ..en1 | **Token2** `// after 1/3 of the time slot, T1 slides away to the left to make space for an eventual T3`\r\n- **Token2** | Token3 `// last 1/3 of the time slot: new T3 appears`\r\n- Token2 | **Token3** `// T2 expired`\r\n- ...\r\n\r\nInstead of bold/regular, better use colored/gray text so that the width doesn't change when a token option to batch assign icons to existing 2FA entries","body":"As a user, I'd like a way to batch assign icons to my existing 2FA entries when I switch to or import an icon pack.\r\n\r\n### Description\r\n\r\nThe goal is to save user time: When a user has multiple (e.g. 30) entries, it is very tedious to set each one manually. This is due to two factors: Each entry is edited one at a time, and the UX for switching icons is not optimized for doing this efficiently (options are in deeply nested menus and require multiple taps from the user).\r\n\r\nAny batch operation will be imperfect because user preferences for icons are nondeterministic. Worst case, this allows the user to assign a majority of icons to entries so that they only need to go back and edit/customize a few entries they are unhappy with. This still saves significant time and improves the usability of the app icons feature.\r\n\r\n### Acceptance Criteria\r\n\r\nThe below acceptance criteria is subject to change by the development team as necessary and reasonable. The initial goal of this list is to give this feature request some substance.\r\n\r\n- Aegis makes a reasonable attempt to assign a default icon to each 2FA entry where reasonable. Examples:\r\n  - Only one icon exists for a service: Choose that one\r\n  - Multiple icons exist for a single service: Choose an application-defined default, such as the first icon in the list. The specific choice algorithm here is irrelevant; only the outcome is important.\r\n- Batch icon assignment is not automatic. Not every user may want to do this, especially those with only a handful of 2FA entries. A conveniently accessible manual option will be provided to the user to batch assign a specific icon pack. Specific UX design is left open to the developer of this user story.\r\n- Appropriate documentation is written instructing users how to use this new feature, including but not limited to:\r\n  - Specific icon-choosing behaviors, such as when icons cannot be chosen automatically and under what conditions this can occur.\r\n  - Explanation and disclaimer stating that automatic icon assignment is imperfect by design. Instruct the users that they can still manually edit icons after batch assignment if they are unhappy with specific icon choices.\r\n\r\n### References, Links\r\n\r\n- Related to #509 (Icon feature","id":1557492076,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/labels/proposal","node_id":"MDU6TGFiZWwxNTU3NDkyMDc2"}],"milestone":null,"events_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/739/events","html_url":"https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/739","reactions":{"confused":0,"-1":0,"total_count":2,"+1":0,"rocket":0,"hooray":0,"eyes":0,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/739/reactions","laugh":0,"heart":2},"assignee":null,"user":{"gists_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/gists{/gist_id}","repos_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/repos","following_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/following{/other_user}","starred_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/starred{/owner}{/repo}","login":"keganlance","followers_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/followers","type":"User","url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance","subscriptions_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/subscriptions","received_events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/received_events","avatar_url":"https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/32643359?v=4","events_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/events{/privacy}","html_url":"https://github.com/keganlance","site_admin":false,"id":32643359,"gravatar_id":"","node_id":"MDQ6VXNlcjMyNjQzMzU5","organizations_url":"https://api.github.com/users/keganlance/orgs"},"node_id":"MDU6SXNzdWU4NzYyMDY2MTc="},{"assignees":[],"created_at":"2021-03-02T04:06:47Z","title":"Dynamically decide KDF parameters and consider implementing caching","body":"TL;DR: Hardcoded KDF values violate NIST guidlines; they are supposed to be set based on device speed.  While you are at it, implement KDF caching using Argon2's \"server relief\" to drastically increase the cost of brute-forcing the vault backups.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nKey Derivation Functions attempt to squeeze additional security out of low-quality secrets by increasing the computational cost of a brute force attack.  The amount a key can be stretched is ultimately limited by usability requirements.  The industry standard practice of hardcoding of specific values technically violate [NIST's KDF guidelines](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-132.pdf):\r\n\r\n> The iteration count shall be selected as large as possible, as long as the time required to generate the key using the entered password is acceptable for the users.\r\n\r\nIndustry hasn't done much about this because increasing KDF values would represent a major expense for service providers and a DoS attack vector.  Part of the rethink done for the password hashing competition was to formalize a technique in which clients would perform the majority of the work for server.  Argon2 calls this \"server relief\" and is provides an error-resistant API.\r\n\r\nWhile Aegis doesn't have a client/server model, abusing  caching can be used to increase the cost for offline attackers while maintaining a good user experience.  The simplest example/implementation of KDF caching would be to set a very high KDF iteration value for the backup vault and cache an intermediate value within the apps' private storage area.  The user would only experience a high KDF wait time during the initial setup and when restoring from a backup.  This wouldn't do much against a root exploit, but it can increase the cost of other attacks by 10-100x.\r\n\r\nThe following KDF run times roughly align with [user perception/delay tolerance](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/response-times-3-important-limits/):\r\n\r\n1. **100ms - 200ms** app closed\r\n2. **[1s - 5s](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/154193120204600511)** phone reboot\r\n3. **1m-10m** initial setup/sync or restoration from backup\r\n\r\nThe first tier provides marginal security gains to a narrow group of high-risk users, like protesters without enough op-sec experience to setup work mode.  The additional complexity is only justifiable if key material is already being flushed from memory to help mitigate side channel attacks.\r\n\r\nThe second tier delay should be masked using an animation that also communicates that the delay helps increase security.  The third tier cache isn't needed for on-device functionality and can be run as a background task.  Users can be expected to tolerate restoring from backups for much longer than normal, as long as you provide accurate feedback on how long the task will take.\r\n\r\nEdge cases in which restoring to a new device would take over an hour or when the new device just doesn't have enough memory can be handled by entering the private key by scanning a QR code or manually entering a mnemonic.","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/697/labels{/name}","author_association":"NONE","number":697,"updated_at":"2021-03-25T00:23:30Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/697/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":819586426,"state":"open","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/697/timeline","state_reason":null,"comments":8,"closed_at":null,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/697","labels":[{"default":false,"color":"84b6eb","name":"proposal","description":"A options for larger text for tokens, and maybe colored text","body":"I really like Aegis, but I think the UI could be improved.\r\n\r\nConsider this: the UI looks very nice and clean when I'm just looking right at it on my phone, but that's often not how it works. Often, I'm looking at it on my desk, out of the corner of my eye, as I type a code for some login. Keep in mind that I have several different services for which I have MFA tokens, and at a glance it's very easy to confuse one for another. Also, I'm likely to be distracted at the time. Somebody tells me that some of our servers are having problems, so I have to quick log into AWS SSO while I'm trying to get more information from them about what's known about the problem at the same time.\r\n\r\nThis was a regular problem for me when I used Google Authenticator 5.0. I would type the code for my corporate LastPass when trying to log into our VPN, and vice versa. And of course, my LastPass password is naturally pretty long and complicated, so the idea that I mistyped in the first time isn't impossible, so I can make the same mistake over and over.\r\n\r\nRecently I ended up downloading and trying every single MFA app I could find on either the Play store or F-Droid. One of my favorites from a UI perspective was actually the [Epic Authenticator](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.epic.authenticator), in spite of its lack of a 3-digit break. The large numbers and automatically-different colors was exactly what I wanted. Now, the Epic app is unacceptable for other reasons, but I think it has some good ideas you could profitably steal.\r\n\r\nSo first of all, I would suggest adding more options for even larger text for the token numbers. I'm fine with only being able to fit 3 or 4 codes on the screen if the numbers are really big and easy to read out of the corner of my eye. Also, you currently stack the service name and the user name for the token above the code, whereas I think an option to put these underneath the icon would allow you to make large token text work better. \r\n\r\nSecond of all, an option to automatically choose a color for the token would aid tremendously in making it easy to locate the correct token when looking at the app from the corner of your eye. Ideally, this would be done in a predictable way, so that the same combination of service name and user name always resulted in the same color. Like you could hash \"Github\" and \"dradetsky\" into an rgb code, or something along those lines. Maybe there's some subset of the full rgb spectrum well known to frontend people to look good & readable on black & white backgrounds respectively. Or maybe you just choose a set of colors which are easy to distinguish from each other, and make the first code always be color0, the second code always be color1, etc.","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/696/labels{/name}","author_association":"NONE","number":696,"updated_at":"2021-08-22T08:52:31Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/696/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":819192336,"state":"open","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/696/timeline","state_reason":null,"comments":1,"closed_at":null,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/696","labels":[{"default":false,"color":"84b6eb","name":"proposal","description":"A Phrase for Backups","body":"TL;DR: The best trade-off between security and usability for off-device backups is a setup workflow/wizard that instructs the user to write down or print off the encryption key.  This is what many online services do when activating 2FA and how most cryptocurrency wallets operate.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\nTOTP apps, password managers, and crypto-currency wallets are all domain-specific secrets managers.  The security model is fundamentally identical, their value comes in isolating failure: Aegis on your phone hedges against a XSS attack against your password manager's browser extension.\r\n\r\nTOTP managers tie a device to an account, protected by the pin/pattern/biometrics of the phone.  The [average pin/pattern has ~14 bits of entropy](https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2015/08/new-data-uncovers-the-surprising-predictability-of-android-lock-patterns/) and can only be meaningfully protected by hardware which limits brute force attempts.  A strong KDF will deter casual attackers and are necessary because hardware security modules are usually buggy propriety blobs which are regularly tricked into going over their limit.  \r\n\r\nFor most users, off-device transfer of TOTP secrets (via device syncing, cloud backups, and vault exports) represent a violation of the isolation between secret managers.  A separate password for backups would only bump the entropy level to ~30 bits; any \"good passwords\" higher than that are prone to being forgotten or fat fingered.\r\n\r\nA better solution is to just store an offline copy of the full secret, possibly with mnemonic and QR encodings.","labels_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/692/labels{/name}","author_association":"NONE","number":692,"updated_at":"2022-11-04T16:54:22Z","performed_via_github_app":null,"comments_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/692/comments","active_lock_reason":null,"repository_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis","id":817824167,"state":"open","locked":false,"timeline_url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/692/timeline","state_reason":null,"comments":13,"closed_at":null,"url":"https://api.github.com/repos/beemdevelopment/Aegis/issues/692","labels":[{"default":false,"color":"84b6eb","name":"proposal","description":"A to libsodium for the scrypt implementation","body":"This drops the dependency we have on SpongyCastle for the implementation of scrypt in favor of the one in libsodium. With this, we fix crashes on low-end devices (#114, #300), get better scrypt performance and pave the way for switching to better crypto primitives in the future as discussed in\r\n[vault.md](https://github.com/beemdevelopment/Aegis/blob/master/docs/vault.md#primitives).\r\n\r\nLibsodium is a C library. I wrote a small JNI binding library for it ([libsodium-android](https://github.com/beemdevelopment/libsodium-android)), as I wasn't happy with the existing options. I placed the .AAR file in source control for now, as I'm not sure where to publish it. I considered GitHub's maven package repository, but apparently it always requires authentication, even for downloading packages. Let's test this first and figure out where we should publish libsodium-android guide","body":"This is as much a help request as it is a feature request. Maybe it's just me, but coming from Authy, where you just scan a barcode (something I just learned isn't recommended) or manually enter the string provided by the service the 2FA is being set up for and then you're done, I'm having a tough time figuring out how to use this. In contrast to the very simple setup of Authy, Aegis requires much more info to be entered and choices to be made, and I have no idea what to put and choose. It would be ideal to have a guide, both in the app and here, on the different fields and what they mean and which options are generally preferred.\r\n\r\n* Name: I assume this would just be whatever label you want to assign, e.g. Email\r\n* Issuer: I assume this would be the site, e.g. Google, Firefox, etc, but it's unclear if it needs to be in any particular format or if it's even necessary. One site I found (https://github.com/google/google-authenticator/wiki/Key-Uri-Format) says it's \"strongly recommended\" but I don't really follow the logic. AFAICT, as long as the labels are unique enough, this isn't needed, but I could be way off.\r\n* TOTP/HOTP/Steam: I know TOTP is the most common, and from what I can tell it's more secure, so I assume it's the recommended one to use unless HOTP is necessary for some reason. Steam is obvious, of course, though I suppose it's possible some users might not know what it is, so still wouldn't be a bad idea to give a quick explanation on it as well.\r\n* SHA1/SHA256/SHA512: I know SHA1 is bad/broken for encryption purposes, and 512 is better than 256, but a) not everyone will know this, b) from what I can tell SHA1 should be fine for OTP, at least TOTP, and c) it's not clear if you can use any of them for any service, or how it would affect the keys provided vs expected.*\r\n* Digits / Time: These ones are obvious, though, as with the hash, it's not clear if/how it would affect the keys.*\r\n* Secret: I assume this is the long string provided by the service in place of a barcode.\r\n\r\n*I don't have an in-depth understanding of how OTP codes are generated and work, obviously, and I always thought that each service has its own, specific way of doing it. So for example, I assumed that if you set up 2FA on Google/Facebook/whatever, the barcode or key would determine how it's calculated, so the generator and the website would always match. Based on that logic, if you change the hash, digit length, or timeout, they wouldn't match. I hesitated for a bit to set up a 2FA because of this, but having been a while since I've set one up, in doing so now I see it has you enter the code from the generator to complete setup, so I'm guessing it determines what various settings you used based on
